content:
There are a number of reasons. I had an antivirus program interfere so much with my Thunderbird profile folder that nothing moved to the junk folder until I removed the antivirus product.

But there can be other issues, like having the profile folder in the documents folder (not a good idea) or even having the prpfile on some sort of cloud backed up location in your local drive.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Copia i messaggi che vuoi tenere solo su Thunderbird in una sotto-cartella di Cartelle Locali Poi cancellali dalla posizione originale.
creator: @next

content: When you click the 'Share full article' icon on a NYT article, one of the choices is Email, and since TB is the default in my Firefox settings for mailto Content type (see picture), clicking Email launches a TB message with a link to the article. With other browsers, it might be a similar setting. With a browser like Edge, I think the best method is to define TB as the default app for mailto links in Windows Settings, Apps, Default apps, Choose defaults by link types.
creator: sfhowes

content: You can attach an email by drag and drop from the message list to a reply message, but it probably makes more sense to right-click your first reply in the Sent folder, Edit As New Message, and add something at the top like "here is the message I sent earlier".
creator: sfhowes

content: Yes, you are correct, it works. Thanks. It takes me a bit of time to find out how to do even this because in Windows 11 the message I am typing fills the screen and I have to go back down to the task bar to find the Thunderbird file list, there doesn't seem to be a way to maintain all the tabs visible on the screen when composing a message, but I guess I just haven't found it. By the way when I get your reply from Mozilla and click on "This solves my problem" in the Mozilla email page, my browser says "Page not found", however if I click on "This doesn't solve my problem", I get to the answer where I can mark it as "This solves my problem". Just mentioning it. Its all far too clever for me. Thanks
creator: old_nic

content: Thunderbird non ha limiti di capienza se non la capacità del disco su cui è memorizzato il suo archivio. Se capisco bene cosa intendi, stai parlando della capienza della tua casella sul server. In tal caso devi rivolgerti a chi gestisce la casella stessa (ad esempio Google per Gmail, Microsoft per Outlook.com, Aruba, Libero, etc)
creator: @next
